results.title: Spitfire over Australia
results.brief_description: During World War II, more than 650 Spitfire aircraft were delivered to the RAAF. This is the story of Colin Pay, who rebuilt one of those magnificent machines, a Vickers Supermarine Spitfire HF Mk VIII built in 1944, from the corroded hulk he acquired in 1982. It is now a superbly restored flying machine. Including some of the best air to air colour footage ever shot of a Spitfire in Australia, and archival footage of Spitfires in Darwin in 1943 and interviews with the pilots who originally flew them, this is the ideal video for avaition enthusiasts!

results.title: Visions of Victoria
results.creator_credit: Stewart Faichney and Janne Martin Video Productions
results.brief_description:
On a continent distinguished for its unique mixture of climates and for its exotic wildlife, there is no state that provides more variety and contrast than Victoria. Occupying the south-east corner of Australia, and only slightly larger than the size of Great Britain, Victoria has something for everybody. This video takes you on a remarkable tour of the state of Victoria which includes the wilderness areas of its world famous national parks, some of the best surf beaches in the world, Australia’s largest inland lagoon system, a rugged shipwrecked coast, winter resorts and high country, wetlands and even deserts. Also the vibrant and sophisticated city of Melbourne, renowned for its beautiful parks and gardens, exciting restaurants and nightlife, its devotion to the arts and, of course, a fanatical love of sports of all kinds. This superb video is a comprehensive celebration of this wonderful state, in all its beauty, seasons and moods.

Note: the end has a segment on film classification showing Bill Collins introducing the “G” rating.

results.title: Words and silk
results.creator_credit: John Cruthers, Philip Tyndall and Kangaroo Films
results.brief_description: A two part program about the life and works of Australian fiction writer, Gerald Murnane. Pt. 1. The imaginary and real world of Gerald Murnane (41 min.) The first part explores his imaginary world and presents images both of Murnane’s childhood in Victoria during the 1940’s and of his interests, particularly his obsession with horseracing. Pt. 2. The real and imaginary world of Gerald Murnane (45 min.) In the second part Murnane discusses his writing style and reads extracts from Tamarisk Row to show how he weaves his interests and obsessions into his work.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Cruthers, Philip Tyndall and Kangaroo Films

results.title: Jack Lindsay
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Videos on Australian Writers: archival writers series II”.
Jack Lindsay speaks about his relationship with his father, Norman Lindsay, and their shared interest in the classical world. He recalls the cultural life of Sydney in the 1920s and his memories of writers Kenneth Slessor, Christopher Brennan and Henry Lawson. Lindsay left Australia in 1926 and remained in England for the rest of his life. A poet, novelist, translator, historian, critic and biographer, Lindsay discusses the influence of political thought on his writing and his involvement in the anti-Facist Union of Poets and the Authors’ World Peace Appeal. He remembers his friendships with fellow poets Dylan Thomas, Edith Sitwell, Aragon, Tristan Tzara and Paul Eluard.

results.title: John Morrison
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Videos on Australian Writers: archival writers series II”.
John Morrison remembers his childhood in Sunderland, England, and how his ambition to write and travel brought him to Australia. A basic wage earner all his life, Morrison wrote prolifically in his spare time and used his work experiences in the bush, as a council worker and on the Melbourne waterfront, as background for his stories. He recalls his association with the trade union press and the Communist Review. A member of Realist Writers, he speaks of his friendship with Frank Davidson and Alan Marshall.

results.title: Manning Clark
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Videos on Australian Writers: archival writers series II”.
Author and historian Manning Clark recalls the events of his early childhood, the attitudes of his family and how they influenced his writing. He speaks at length about the process of researching and writing his multi- volume History of Australia and how his outlook changed over the years of writing it. He speaks candidly about the public reaction to his work and addresses his critics. Interviewed by James Murdoch during Australia’s bicentennial year, 1988, Clark reflects on the past and expresses his hopes for the future of Australian society.

results.title: Joan Lindsay
results.creator_credit: Ian McKay, AAV Australia and Australia Council
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Videos on Australian Writers: archival writers series II”.
In this interview with John Taylor, Joan Lindsay speaks about her experiences as an art student at the National Gallery School in Melbourne and her decision to become a writer. She talks about her marriage to the painter Daryl Lindsay. Lindsay describes the process of writing her novel, “Picnic at Hanging Rock”, and her preoccupation with time as a theme. Related to both the Boyd and Lindsay families, she gives a unique insight into the personalities of some of Australia’s leading artists.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ian McKay, AAV Australia and Australia Council

results.title: Olaf Ruhen
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Videos on Australian Writers: archival writers series II”.
Researched and interviewed by James Murdoch, author Olaf Ruhen recalls a life travelling throughout Australia and the South Pacific gathering materials for his books. He speaks of his love of the sea and his affinity with the Tongan people. Ruhen recalls his friendship with the painter, Albert Namatjira. A visit to a writers’ conference in New York inspired Ruhen to create a forum for Australian authors, the Australian Society of Authors.

results.title: Robert D. Fitzgerald
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Videos on Australian Writers: archival writers series II”.
Acclaimed poet Robert D. Fitzgerald describes himself as a “professional surveyor and an amateur poet”. He recalls his experiences working for the Native Lands Commission in the remote interior regions of Fiji which inspired his poem “Between two tides”. Fitzgerald remembers his friendship with fellow writers Kenneth Slessor, Jack and Phillip Lindsay, Douglas Stewart and Dame Mary Gilmore. During the Vietnam war, Fitzgerald was active in the anti-war movement. He discusses the reasons for his involvement and recalls the events surrounding the Arts Vietnam protest.

results.title: How often do you think about the Roman Empire?
results.material_description: digital screen recording of @idkhowyoufoundme's TikTok stream
results.brief_description: Women asking men this question conquered the internet in September. What makes this example funny is the man’s surprise at such a specific question. Like most videos in the trend, the man goes from confused to slightly defensive when he realises that he actually thinks about ancient Rome a lot. The viral meme seems to have revealed that men, collectively, think about aqueducts from antiquity regularly. It started as a text post on Instagram but has become a prank-style template, but it’s also sometimes considered alongside the red/beige flag relationship trend and the popularity of stoicism videos on the manosphere.
results.title_for_label: How often do you think about the Roman Empire?
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

Women asking men this question conquered the internet in September. What makes this example funny is the man’s surprise at such a specific question. Like most videos in the trend, the man goes from confused to slightly defensive when he realises that he actually thinks about ancient Rome a lot. The viral meme seems to have revealed that men, collectively, think about aqueducts from antiquity regularly. It started as a question on Instagram but has become a prank-style template, but it’s also at times considered alongside the ‘red/beige’ flag relationship trend and the popularity of ancient Western civilisation on the misogynistic manosphere.

According to Know Your Meme:

Many are wondering if it’s a “red flag” if their male partner thinks about the Roman empire all the time. In some of the videos, the men sometimes answer “never,” and in the comment section, many women joke, “He’s a keeper.”

That intersection between the Roman Empire trend and the ‘red flag’ trend can be interpreted as identifying toxic masculinity. Online trolls and misogynists are at times inspired by examples of hyper-masculinity in antiquity as justification for a return to outdated gender norms. Ronald Levant, a professor emeritus of psychology at The University of Akron and author of The Tough Standard: The Hard Truths About Masculinity and Violence told USA Today that men may “gravitate to a society that glorified male strength” as they feel lost in the world.
description_for_label: Women asking men this question conquered the internet in September. What makes this example funny is the man’s surprise at such a specific question. Like most videos in the trend, he goes from confused to defensive when he realises he actually thinks about Rome a lot, like many other men according to the virality of the trend. Though a light-hearted prank-style meme, it can also be interpreted as demonstrating the link between idolising ancient Western history and toxic masculinity. To find out how, collect this display on your Lens and read more online.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Minds → MM-09. Catch of the Day
